Generation III.Ruby: This Pok é mon has a body of steel. To make its body, Aron feeds on iron ore that it digs from mountains. Occasionally, it causes major trouble by eating bridges and rails.
Generation III.Sapphire: Aron has a body of steel. With one all-out charge, this Pok é mon can demolish even a heavy dump truck. The destroyed dump truck then becomes a handy meal for the Pok é mon .
Generation III.Emerald: A Pok é mon that is clad in steel armor. A new suit of armor is made when it evolves. The old, discarded armor is salvaged as metal for making iron products.
Generation III.FireRed: It eats iron to build its steel body. It is a pest that descends from mountains to eat bridges and train tracks.
Generation III.LeafGreen: It eats iron to build its steel body. It is a pest that descends from mountains to eat bridges and train tracks.

Generation IV.Diamond: It usually lives deep in mountains. However, hunger may drive it to eat railroad tracks and cars.
Generation IV.Pearl: It usually lives deep in mountains. However, hunger may drive it to eat railroad tracks and cars.
Generation IV.Platinum: It usually lives deep in mountains. However, hunger may drive it to eat railroad tracks and cars.
Generation IV.HeartGold: When it evolves, it sheds the steel carapace that covered its whole body and develops a new one.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: When it evolves, it sheds the steel carapace that covered its whole body and develops a new one.

Generation V.Black: It usually lives deep in mountains. However, hunger may drive it to eat railroad tracks and cars.
Generation V.White: It usually lives deep in mountains. However, hunger may drive it to eat railroad tracks and cars.
Generation V.Black 2: In order to build up its steel body, it eats iron ore. This pesky Pokémon is known to eat railroad tracks.
Generation V.White 2: In order to build up its steel body, it eats iron ore. This pesky Pokémon is known to eat railroad tracks.

Generation VI.X: It usually lives deep in mountains. However, hunger may drive it to eat railroad tracks and cars.
Generation VI.Y: When it evolves, it sheds the steel carapace that covered its whole body and develops a new one.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: This Pokémon has a body of steel. To make its body, Aron feeds on iron ore that it digs from mountains. Occasionally, it causes major trouble by eating bridges and rails.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Aron has a body of steel. With one all-out charge, this Pokémon can demolish even a heavy dump truck. The destroyed dump truck then becomes a handy meal for the Pokémon.

Generation VIII.Sword: It eats iron ore—and sometimes railroad tracks— to build up the steel armor that protects its body.
Generation VIII.Shield: When Aron evolves, its steel armor peels off. In ancient times, people would collect Aron's shed armor and make good use of it in their daily lives.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It usually lives deep in mountains. But when it's hungry, it shows up at the foot of the mountains and eats railroad tracks and cars.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It usually lives deep in mountains. But when it's hungry, it shows up at the foot of the mountains and eats railroad tracks and cars.

Generation IV.HeartGold: Safari Zone (tall grass in Rocky Beach with 24 Peak points)
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Safari Zone (tall grass in Rocky Beach with 24 Peak points)

Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Granite Cave Victory Road ( Horde Encounter )
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Granite Cave Victory Road ( Horde Encounter )

Generation VIII.Expansion Pass: Lakeside Cave Ballimere Lake ( Wanderer ) Slippery Slope , Giant's Bed , Snowslide Slope , Frigid Sea , Ballimere Lake ( Max Raid Battle )
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Fuego Ironworks ( Poké Radar ) Grand Underground - Rocky Cave , Big Bluff Cavern , Whiteout Cave , Icy Cave , Glacial  Cavern (After obtaining the National Pokédex )
